title: Chifforobe
text:
A chifforobe (), also chiffarobe or chifferobe, is a closet-like piece of furniture that combines a long space for hanging clothes (that is, a <a href="wardrobe">wardrobe</a> or <a href="armoire">armoire</a>) with a <a href="chest%20of%20drawers">chest of drawers</a>. Typically the wardrobe section runs down one side of the piece, while the drawers occupy the other side. It may have two enclosing doors or have the drawer fronts exposed and a separate door for the hanging space.
Chifforobes were first advertised in the 1908 <a href="Sears%2C%20Roebuck%20and%20Company">Sears, Roebuck</a> Catalogue, which described them as "a modern invention, having been in use only a short time." The term itself is a <a href="portmanteau">portmanteau</a> of the words "<a href="chiffonier">chiffonier</a>" and "wardrobe".
The word is used in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, primarily in the <a href="Southern%20United%20States">southern</a> portion of the country, in <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a>, and in <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>. Its use has been attested as far apart as <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a> and <a href="Vermont">Vermont</a>. In those references, it was used as a <a href="water%20closet">water closet</a> or <a href="Chamber%20pot">potty</a> (or more accurately a <a href="commode">commode</a>). The word has been used in <a href="Texas">Texas</a>, but is not as common as its synonyms such as "<a href="Chest%20of%20drawers">bureau</a>" or "<a href="Chest%20of%20drawers">dresser</a>".
